Class XMLParser

[line 65]

Location: /xml.class.php




Remarks


XMLParser class


This class parses a given XML data to a multidimensional array by using  a user-defined tag. The default tag is <graph>. The example below explains  how the class works.  

1      <?php
2      $xml_data = "<root>
3                   <graph color='234,234,233' label='string'>x^2+5</graph>
4                   <another_tag name='tag'>This tag</another_tag>
5                   <graph>x^2+5</graph>
6                   </root>";
7     
8      $xml = new XMLParser($xml_data);
9      print_r($xml->CreateInputArray());
10     ?>
11     OUTPUT:
12     Array
13     (
14       [0] => Array
15           (
16               [0] => Array
17                   (
18                       [color] => 234,234,233
19                       [label] => string
20                   )
21               [1] => x^2+5
22           )
23       [1] => Array
24           (
25               [0] => x^2+5
26           )
27     )

	
usedby

		
RenderWikiPlot()

	
usedby

		
XMLParser::CreateInputArray()

Method Detail



    



    XMLParser::XMLParser
    


    
XMLParser(
string
$Data );

    



		
    Parameters
    
			
    $Data
    
		
    XML Input Data from user
    
		
    Remarks
    

    Constructor of XMLParser class
    

    The function initializes the fallowing variables:  $Parser, $Input, $Tags, $Attributes and $Separator.  It makes it possible to use XML Parser within an object  by using the function xml_set_object. Besides it uses also  two more XML Parser Functions xml_set_element_handler(),  xml_set_character_data_handler() and xml_parser_free().

    XMLParser::CreateInputArray
    


    
CreateInputArray(
 );

    



	
    Remarks
    

    Creates an array containing all parsed XML data
    

    The function runs each and every tag in the $Tags array  through the XMLParser object. The parsed data is then  stored in the $Graph which is returned at the end of the  proces.
    
	
    uses
    
		
    XMLParser
    
	
    uses
    
		
    XMLParser::$Tags
    
	
    access
    
		
    public
    
	
    [ Top ]
    

    



    XMLParser::CreateTagArray
    


    
CreateTagArray(
 );

    



	
    Remarks
    

    Puts parsed data into an array
    

    The function takes the variables $Attributes and $TagData and  puts them into an array called $Tag. The first element in the  array will be Attribute(s) of the interested tag and the second  element will be the data of the tag. If Attribute does not exist  the first element will then be the data of the tag.
    
	
    usedby
    
		
    XMLParser::Parse()
    
	
    uses
    
		
    XMLParser::$Tag
    
	
    uses
    
		
    XMLParser::$TagData
    
	
    uses
    
		
    XMLParser::$Attributes
    
	
    access
    
		
    private

    XMLParser::ExplodeInputData
    


    
ExplodeInputData(
 );

    



	
    Remarks
    

    Findes the interested tag in XML Data
    

    The function uses explode() function and the $Separator to finde  the interested tag in the given XML Data. When the tags are found  it puts them into array called $Tags.
    
	
    usedby

    XMLParser::Parse
    


    
Parse(
string
$Data );

    



		
    Parameters
    
			
    $Data
    
		
    
		
    Remarks
    

    Parses the given XML data
    

    The function uses xml_parse() function from XML Parser Functions in PHP  and parses only the first tag in the given XML data and ignores  everything else. So you can not use it for multitag XML data.  The function also calls CreateTagArray() to generate tag attribute(s)  and data to an array.
    
	
    usedby
    
		
    XMLParser::XMLParser()
    
	
    uses
    
		
    XMLParser::CreateTagArray()
    
	
    access
    
		
    private
    
	
    [ Top ]

  • $Attributes =  [line 122]
    • 

  • Data type: array
    • 


    Remarks
    

    Attributes of interested tag
    

    The variable will always be an array whether the interested tag has any  attributes or not. If the interested tag has any attribute the $Attributes  variable will be used otherwise it will be ignored.
    
	
    usedby
    
		
    XMLParser::OpenTag()

  • $Separator =  [line 157]
    • 

  • Data type: string
    • 


    Remarks
    

    The interested tag
    

    The variable is our iterested tag. It means the tag that we are  iterested to finde in the given XML data.  The way you should definde your interested tag is as follows:  If your interested tag is <Tag> than you should change the  $Separator variable to XMLParser::Separator = "<Tag" not "<Tag>"  or something else!
    
	
    usedby
    
		
    XMLParser::ExplodeInputData()
    
	
    access
    
		
    public
    

    


  • $Tag =  [line 111]
    • 

  • Data type: array
    • 


    Remarks
    

    An interested tag in given XML data
    

    The variable stores attribute(s) and data of an interested tag not  the tag it selv <tag>. For example:  

    1      If this is an interested tag
    2      <graph color='23,25,200' lable='string'>2x^3+3x</graph> the variable
    3      Variable $Tag will look like this:
    4      Array
    5      (
    6         [0] => Array
    7                (
    8                   [color] => 23,25,200
    9                   [lable] => string
    10               )
    11        [1] => 2x^3+3x
    12     )
      As you can see the first element in the array is an array and it  will always be an array if the interested tag has attribute(s). The second  element in the array will be the data of the tag as string. One more thing  to be notes is that the array can not contain more then two elements, while one  element is possible.
    
	
    usedby
    
		
    XMLParser::CreateTagArray()
    
	
    access
    
		
    private

    Remarks
    

    Data of the tag
    

    The variable will store the data of the tag. For example  <tag> tag data </tag>  $TagData = "tag data";
